title: Can someone share my personal information without my consent? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on the nature of the information, and what you define as personal, but the basic answer is yes, they can share it without your consent. Most data about people has almost no legal protection. This is why it’s legal for gMail to read and analyze your emails looking for topics they can use to categorize you for advertisers. It’s why Facebook can do the same, even in your chats using Facebook Messenger. It’s why it’s legal for VR games and even your weather app to collect your minute-to-minute GPS track 24 hours a day, and sell it to advertisers or anyone else willing to buy it. It’s why your supermarket offers you a discount membership card, so they can sell lists of all the products you buy. The list is endless. There are a few precious restrictions, but not many. For example, healthcare providers must safeguard medical information about you quite carefully. The IRS must protect the confidentiality of your tax returns, and the courts must protect records that have been sealed by a judge. But even then, if by negligence, error or intent any of that information leaks to a third party, there are very few limitations on their ability to share it even more widely, entirely without your consent. This does not mean that such things are entirely without consequences. In certain instances you could initiate a civil lawsuit in an effort to collect damages, but the burden would be on you to prove that the data was legally privileged in the first place, and to prove that their actions were instrumental in causing you harm. But that only applies to a very narrow band of information… almost all of the personal data about you flying back and forth in our digital domains is legally naked. And thus so are you.  NOTE: This is NOT legal advice, which can only come from an attorney licensed to practice law in the relevant jurisdiction.

Whether or not someone can share your personal information without your consent depends on what that “personal information” is. Some types of personal information the law treats as being confidential; other types of information is not treated as being confidential and people can share it freely. Statutes that create a duty of confidentiality — In the United States, some sorts of information are considered to be so sensitive that laws have been passed to help preserve the confidentiality of that information. For instance, the federal Privacy Act prohibits the Social Security Administration from disclosing your Social Security Number unless strict procedures are followed to ensure that the information is protected. Invasion of privacy — Even if no statute has been passed that prohibits someone from disclosing sensitive information, there are some types of information that the law treats as being private. If someone discloses that information about you without your consent, you can sue that person for invasion of privacy. For instance, if someone sneaked a camera into your bedroom and filmed you while you were changing your clothing, that would be invasion of privacy. Information that is not confidential — Most of your personal information is not considered to be sensitive, and people can share that information without your consent. For instance, if you graduated from college, bought a new car, or changed jobs, that would not be confidential information.

Let me rephrase your question in terms of the General Data Protection Act (GDPR): Can personal data be shared without consent? In short: yes, where there is another lawful basis for data sharing. Consent is one of five lawful grounds for data processing you can choose from. Select always the most appropriate one, the one that best reflects the purpose and methods of your data processing practices. When (most likely) do you need consent? when you process sensitive data categories (the consent should be then valid, lawful and explicit)when you have no other lawful basis for data processing. The other lawful grounds are:A contract with the individual: for example, to supply goods or services they have requested, or to fulfil an obligation under an employee contract.Compliance with a legal obligation: when processing data for a particular purpose is a legal requirement.Vital interests: for example, when processing data will protect someone’s physical integrity or life (either the data subject’s or someone else’s).A public task: for example, to complete official functions or tasks in the public interest. This will typically cover public authorities such as government departments, schools and other educational institutions; hospitals; and the police.Legitimate interests: when a private-sector organisation has a genuine and legitimate reason (including commercial benefit) to process personal data without consent, provided it is not outweighed by negative effects to the individual’s rights and freedoms.when you process data for some marketing purposes (and you want to install cookie files on users devices or track them with other intrusive technologies) - these rules are expressed in Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations 2003 (PECR) which might be replaced by ePrivacy Regulation. Please note that if you need consent by ePrivacy means, you need it too in terms of GDPR.Seeking valid consent for data processing is good data protection practice and it gives users the highest level of control over what happens to their data. If you want some further reading, please see the relevant provisions in GDPR.

It depends on who this person is. If a person is professionally bound by ethics - an attorney, a medical professional, a therapist, or clergy - then an authorized release of information can be punishable by law.Recovery of any damages is a whole another story. If this person has no obligation to keep your informaiton private - anyone from a stranger to a friend to a relative - then you can consider yourself as exposed to such a possibility.Hope you have shared information only with those whom you have complete trust in.

I would imagine it depends on what that information is. For example, if there’s information out there already, like your address or phone number, where there’s a good chance it could reasonably be discovered by anyone looking that’s probably not going to give you much to fight against. Unless it’s in the context of employment and your company has a policy against providing employee information to outside parties. If the information is not otherwise available to anyone looking, like something in your medical history or even class grades from university that were shared in confidence with a friend or other trusted person, you may have a basis for legal action against them. Especially if you’re able to show that there was malicious intent and also financial or other damages that occurred as a result of the unauthorized disclosure of your information. If it’s an organization who released your information without your prior approval, you have a case.

In most cases yes. Unless you have an attorney draw up a non disclosure agreement and both parties sign it. Even then there are usually terms which may make the agreement null and void should they occur. That very circumstance is being argued out as we speak, between attorneys for porn star Stormy Daniels and President Donald Trump. Daniels claims that Trump violated terms of the agreement, thus making it null and void, freeing her to speak openly without restriction as she may wish.

Yes. You have no right to privacy, or to your own personal information. When the law requires that you be taken off a list when you ask, that too isn’t done. Where the law requires someone to delete information, the agency using the information licenses it from someone else, so the deletion is only done in a front-company that doesn’t actually hold your information. The only exception is medical records, those are generally private by law. So no, you can’t stop someone talking about your past, unless the stories are designed to harm you. In the US, the truth is generally a defense for defamation (but not always, and the defendant/respondent must prove truth). What you want is a restraining order. Talk to a family lawyer about your options.

response.answer_text: Depends on the country, how you are sharing, and what your relationship is with the person whose data you have. Can you gossip with your co-workers? Yes. Can Facebook post private details on their users in Germany? No, that would be illegal under their privacy laws. You really need to ask a more specific question if you want details. Especially listing a country if you are asking about the laws that govern that scenario.

Depends where you are, in Britain the data protection act makes it illegal to distribute personal information without permission. That's not to say it doesn't happen, in fact I'm pretty sure it happens every day
Yes. It is called gossip. There are selected relationships where such sharing is forbidden; for example a physician may not share your information without your consent.
